problem.p: Evaluate [mathjaxinline]P_{\text err,opt}[/mathjaxinline] in the following four cases. Please enter math symbols using asciimath-like conventions, e.g. [mathjaxinline]\sigma _1[/mathjaxinline] as [mathjaxinline]{\tt sigma\_ 1}[/mathjaxinline], and [mathjaxinline]\sqrt{1-x}[/mathjaxinline] as [mathjaxinline]{\tt sqrt(1-x)}[/mathjaxinline]; also, please make sure to explicitly denote multiplication operations, e.g. [mathjaxinline]x + 2y[/mathjaxinline] should be entered as [mathjaxinline]{\tt x + 2 * y}[/mathjaxinline], and [mathjaxinline]x(1-y)[/mathjaxinline] should be entered as [mathjaxinline]{\tt x * (1-y)}[/mathjaxinline].

solution.span: In this case, [mathjaxinline]\Delta = - p_1 \sigma _1[/mathjaxinline]. Since [mathjaxinline]\sigma _1[/mathjaxinline] is a normalized state, all of eigenvalues of [mathjaxinline]\Delta[/mathjaxinline] are nonpositive, and their absolute values sum to [mathjaxinline]p_1[/mathjaxinline]. Hence the optimal error probability is [mathjaxinline]p_1 - p_1 = 0[/mathjaxinline]. (Indeed, we will have zero probability of error by always guessing that the state is [mathjaxinline]\sigma _1[/mathjaxinline]!)

In this case, [mathjaxinline]\Delta = (p_2 - p_1)\sigma _1 = (1 - 2p_1)\sigma _1[/mathjaxinline]. Since [mathjaxinline]p_1 \geq 1/2[/mathjaxinline], the eigenvalues of [mathjaxinline]\Delta[/mathjaxinline] are all nonpositive and their absolute values sum to [mathjaxinline](2p_1 - 1)[/mathjaxinline]. Hence the optimal error probability is [mathjaxinline]p_1 - (2p_1 - 1) = 1 - p_1 = p_2[/mathjaxinline]. (Indeed, since [mathjaxinline]\sigma _1[/mathjaxinline] and [mathjaxinline]\sigma _2[/mathjaxinline] are identical, no measurement can give us any information about which state it is, so we just always guess the more likely state [mathjaxinline]\sigma _1[/mathjaxinline]).

li.p: [mathjaxinline]p_1 = p_2 = 1/2[/mathjaxinline] and [mathjaxinline]\sigma _1,\sigma _2[/mathjaxinline] are arbitrary. Express your answer in terms of [mathjaxinline]x \equiv \| \sigma _1 - \sigma _2\| _1[/mathjaxinline].

solution.span: In this case, [mathjaxinline]\Delta = \frac{1}{2}(\sigma _2 - \sigma _1)[/mathjaxinline], and [mathjaxinline]{\rm Tr}[\Delta ] = 0[/mathjaxinline]. Hence [mathjaxinline]\sum _{i:\lambda _ i < 0} |\lambda _ i| = \sum _{i:\lambda _ i \geq 0} \lambda _ i[/mathjaxinline], so [mathjaxinline]\| \Delta \| _1 = \sum _{i} \lambda _ i = 2 \sum _{i:\lambda _ i < 0} |\lambda _ i|[/mathjaxinline]. Consequently, the optimal probability of error is [mathjaxinline]\frac{1}{2} - \frac{1}{2} \| \Delta \| _1 = \frac{1}{2} - \frac{1}{4} \| \sigma _1 - \sigma _2 \| _1[/mathjaxinline].

li.p: [mathjaxinline]p_1=p_2=1/2[/mathjaxinline], [mathjaxinline]\sigma _1 = \left|\psi _1\right\rangle \left\langle \psi _1\right|[/mathjaxinline], [mathjaxinline]\sigma _2=\left|\psi _2\right\rangle \left\langle \psi _2\right|[/mathjaxinline]. Express your answer in terms of [mathjaxinline]y \equiv |\langle {\psi _1}|{\psi _2}\rangle |^2[/mathjaxinline].

solution.span:
By the result of the previous part, this reduces to computing [mathjaxinline]\| \left|\psi _1\right\rangle \left\langle \psi _1\right| - \left|\psi _2\right\rangle \left\langle \psi _2\right|\|[/mathjaxinline]. This matrix is supported on the two-dimensional subspace spanned by [mathjaxinline]|{\psi _1}\rangle[/mathjaxinline] and [mathjaxinline]|{\psi _2}\rangle[/mathjaxinline]. Let [mathjaxinline]\{ |{\psi _1}\rangle , |{\phi }\rangle \}[/mathjaxinline] be an orthonormal basis of this subspace, such that we can write [mathjaxinline]|{\psi _2}\rangle = \alpha |{\psi _1}\rangle + \beta |{\phi }\rangle[/mathjaxinline]. Then in this basis,
[mathjax]\left|\psi _1\right\rangle \left\langle \psi _1\right| - \left|\psi _2\right\rangle \left\langle \psi _2\right| = \begin{pmatrix} 1 - |\alpha |^2 & -\alpha \beta ^* \\ -\alpha ^* \beta & -|\beta |^2 \end{pmatrix}.[/mathjax]Â This matrix is Hermitian, and hence has real eigenvalues. Its trace is [mathjaxinline]0[/mathjaxinline] while the determinant is [mathjaxinline]|\alpha \beta |^2 - |\beta |^2 - |\alpha \beta |^2 = -|\beta |^2[/mathjaxinline]. Hence the two eigenvalues are [mathjaxinline]\pm |\beta |[/mathjaxinline], and its Schatten [mathjaxinline]1[/mathjaxinline]-norm is [mathjaxinline]2|\beta |[/mathjaxinline]. Recalling that [mathjaxinline]|\alpha |^2 +|\beta |^2 = 1[/mathjaxinline] and [mathjaxinline]\alpha = \langle {\psi _1}|{\psi _2}\rangle[/mathjaxinline], we see that [mathjaxinline]|\beta | = \sqrt{1 - |\langle {\psi _1}|{\psi _2}\rangle |^2}[/mathjaxinline]. Substituting into the result of the previous part, we find that the optimal error probability is [mathjaxinline]\frac{1}{2} - \frac{1}{2} \sqrt{1 - |\langle {\psi _1}|{\psi _2}\rangle |^2}[/mathjaxinline].
